Riverside Energy Center, LLC (Riverside Energy), a subsidiary of Calpine Corporation, owns the Riverside Energy Center (REC), a combined-cycle electric power generating facility located just north of the city of Beloit, in Rock County, Wisconsin.  The Riverside facility includes two Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems that use ammonia for the reduction of nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions.  The ammonia is stored in aqueous form in two 12,000-gallon storage tanks located at the Riverside facility.  At full capacity, the tanks can store up to 185,040 pounds of aqueous ammonia.  Since the Riverside facility will be storing more than 20,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia in a process, it is subject to United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations codified in 40CFR Part 68.

Ammonia is an easily liquefiable colorless gas with a sharp, intensely irritating odor.  The aqueous form is a solution of ammonia and water.  It is listed by the USEPA as a regulated toxic substance for release prevention.

Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
Pursuant to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations (40 CFR Part 68) Riverside Energy developed this comprehensive written program to protect employees and the surrounding community from exposure to ammonia.  As part of the re-submittal process, Riverside Energy conducts a comprehensive review every five years and revises the RMP accordingly.

Riverside Energy is committed to the safe operation of the SCR ammonia system at the Riverside facility.  A release prevention program has been developed and implemented by Riverside Energy that is a combination of several programs at the facility.  The release prevention program includes employee education in the hazards of aqueous ammonia and measures that can be used to reduce employee and community exposure to accidental releases of ammonia.  The program includes preventive maintenance programs (mechanical integrity) for the ammonia sys

tem that incorporates inspections of the system in accordance with recognized standards of equipment inspection within the ammonia industry, as well as tests of system components in accordance with component manufacturers¿ recommendations.

The release prevention program includes programs for pre-startup safety reviews and management of changes (MOC) to the ammonia system.  The program also includes specific requirements for safe work practices (such as safe approaches to welding and similar hot work) and safety requirements for contractors who may be hired to work on the systems.  

Special emphasis is placed on handling accidental releases of ammonia and coordination of emergency response with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations in the release prevention program.

As part of the release prevention program requirements, Riverside Energy undertook a review of the potential offsite consequences of the accidental releases from two 12,000-gallon aqueous ammonia storage tanks.  Although such a release is highly unlikely, the regulation requires this review.

Worst-Case Release Scenario
As required by USEPA regulations, the worst-case release scenario was assumed to be the complete loss of the contents of two 12,000-gallon storage tanks containing 185,040 pounds of aqueous ammonia.  This analysis included a common containment dike for both tanks as a passive mitigation measure.  The USEPA guidance for defining a worst-case release scenario for a release of gas is to estimate the release rate over a 10-minute period of the largest quantity resulting from a pipe or vessel failure.  Thus, the ammonia emission rate from the worst-case release scenario used was the loss of 185,040 pounds of aqueous ammonia averaged over a 10-minute period, (i.e., approximately 62.9 lbs./min. of ammonia released to the air.)

USEPA¿s public-domain RMP*Comp model was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/lit (or 200 ppm).  The model predic

ted a distance of 0.4 miles as the distance to the toxic endpoint due to the specified worst-case release.  Based on LandView 6 output, the total population within the potential exposure area is 45 with the following public receptors being potentially impacted ¿ residences and industrial areas.

Riverside Energy personnel follow the release prevention program which includes one round inspection per shift for a total of two inspections daily, annual calibration of the ammonia sensors, annual personnel training, and implementation of a preventive maintenance schedule based on the manufacturer¿s recommendations.  In addition, the ammonia tank is a permitted unfired pressure vessel and requires a visual inspection every three years in order to maintain certification from the Department of Commerce.  These measures greatly minimize the chance that the tanks will fully discharge their contents in a release and minimizes the potential for an offsite impact.

Alternative Release Scenario
For the Riverside facility, the alternative release scenario was assumed to be the structural failure of a 2-inch pipe filled with aqueous ammonia under pressure at 56-psig pressure beyond the confines of the concrete dike.  It is assumed that active mitigation (use of emergency shutdown systems) starts within a reasonable time after the accidental release begins.  The pump can be remotely shut down from the control room when loss of pressure is detected.  For this analysis, the total release duration is assumed to be the time period from the beginning of the release event until the release is totally contained.  The total release duration was assumed to be 10 minutes.  In this analysis, no passive mitigation measures were assumed.  Thus, the ammonia emission rate from the alternative release scenario is given as the loss of 457 pounds of aqueous ammonia averaged over a 10-minute period.  This was based on a pumping rate of 2.5 gallons per minute and a density of ammonia of 7.44 pounds per

gallon.  This scenario resulted in a release rate of ammonia to outside air of approximately 2.87 lbs/min.

USEPA¿s public-domain RMP*Comp model was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/lit (or 200 ppm).  The model predicted a distance of 0.1 mile as the distance to the toxic endpoint due to the specified alternative release.  Based on LandView 6 output, the total population within the potential exposure area is 0.  There are no public receptors that will be potentially impacted. 

As stated earlier, Riverside Energy personnel follow the Release Prevention Program in order to minimize the potential for system leaks.  The ¿daily round¿ inspection conducted during each shift, in combination with the continuous monitoring of tank pressure from the control room, can quickly detect any leaks that are present.  In addition, the ammonia pumps are shutdown when the generating units are not operating. These simple prevention techniques significantly reduce the potential for an offsite impact.

Release Prevention Program
As indicated earlier, Riverside Energy pro-actively implements the release prevention program for the SCR ammonia system.  The scope of the release prevention program encompasses various facets of release prevention; e.g., it engenders employee participation, increases employee awareness about the hazards of handling ammonia, establishes safe standard operating procedures, and enhances access to process safety information through annual training being provided by the vendor and hands-on training.   During the design process, Riverside Energy performed a hazards analysis on the SCR ammonia system.  Subsequent hazard reviews were performed after three years and again after 5 years to review the existing operating procedures and equipment maintenance schedule.  These operational safeguard measures indicate a high success rate as demonstrated through no reported leaks or releases.
